description:
But first, kayaking the length of the Grand Canyon is a considerable challenge. It's 277 miles of fearsome rapids and roaring water. But imagine doing it if you were blind. That's exactly what Erik Weihenmayer and Lonnie Bedwell have just done. Erik is no stranger to adventure. He was the first blind man to climb Mount Everest and has also climbed the highest peaks on six other continents. Lonnie, who is an ex-soldier, lost his sight in a hunting accident when he was 31, while Erik was born with a condition which meant he became blind as a teenager. I asked him how it affected his attitude to life.

I just decided, I guess, subconsciously that I was gonna try things that got thrown in front of me and my parents were really encouraging. And so I took part in this recreational programme for blind kids who missed out on ball sports. They'd take us horseback riding and canoeing. One weekend they took us rock climbing. It was up in New Hampshire. And I remember feeling the rock face and running my hands up the wall and just thinking how insane this was and how incredibly adventuresome it was. You know, feeling my way up the rock face, sort of connecting the dots in this puzzle in the rock with my hands and my feet as my eyes, and just getting to the top of this little buttress and thinking: Wow. I mean, life is adventure.
